section.title: Introduction
section.para: There are currently two principle groups of changes that distinguish Shorewall 5 from Shorewall 4:

listitem.para: Cruft Removal - over the years, as new ways to accomplish various tasks are added to Shorewall, support for the old way of doing things has generally been retained but deprecated. Shorewall 5 drops support for those deprecated features.

Changes to CLI commands - In order to make command names more accurately reflect what the associated commands do, a number of commands have been renamed or the function that they perform has been changed.

section.para: Each of these groups is described in more detail in the sections that follow.

section.title: Cruft Removal
section.para: Removal of superseded features makes the code cleaner and easier to extend while also reducing compilation and execution time. The following subsections detail the features that are no longer supported in Shorewall 5.

section.title: Scripts Compiled with Shorewall 4.4.7 or Earlier
section.para: Shorewall 5 cannot correctly run scripts compiled with Shorewall 4.4.7 or earlier releases. Such scripts must be recompiled with 4.4.8 or later prior to upgrading to Shorewall 5.

section.title: Workarounds
section.para: Over the years, a number of workarounds have been added to Shorewall to work around defects in other products. In current distributions, those defects have been corrected, and in 4.6.11, a WORKAROUNDS configuration option was added to disable those workarounds. In Shorewall 5, the WORKAROUNDS setting is still available in the shorewall[6].conf files but:

listitem.para: Its default setting has been changed to No.
All workarounds for old distributions have been eliminated.

section.para: If there is a need to add new workarounds in the future, those workarounds will be enabled by WORKAROUNDS=Yes.

section.title: Removal of Configuration Options
section.para: A number of configuration options have been eliminated in Shorewall 5. The following options have been eliminated and the functionality that they enabled is been removed:
A compilation warning is issued when any of these options are encountered in the .conf file, and the shorewall[6] update command will remove them from the configuration file.
These options have been eliminated because they have been superseded by newer options.

A fatal compilation error is emitted if any of these options are present in the .conf file, and the shorewall[6] update command will replace these options with equivalent setting of the options that supersede them.

section.title: Obsolete Configuration Files
section.para: Support has been removed for the 'blacklist', 'tcrules', 'routestopped', 'notrack' and 'tos' files.

The -t and -b options of the update command are still available to convert the 'tcrules' and 'tos' files to the equivalent 'mangle' file and to convert the 'blacklist' file into an equivalent 'blrules' file.

As in Shorewall 4.6.12, the -s option is available to convert the 'routestopped' file into the equivalent 'stoppedrules' file and the -n option is available to convert a 'notrack' file to the equivalent 'conntrack' file.

Format-2 macro and action files have these columns:
Notice that the first five columns of both sets are the same.

In Shorewall 5, support for format-1 macros and actions has been dropped and all macros and actions will be processed as if ?FORMAT 2 were included before the first entry. Given that the vast majority of actions and macros only use the first five columns, this change will be of no concern to most users, but will cause compilation errors if columns beyold the fifth one are populated.

section.title: COMMENT, FORMAT and SECTION Lines
section.para: COMMENT, FORMAT and SECTION Lines now require the leading question mark ("?"). In earlier releases, the question mark was optional. The shorewall[6] update -D command will insert the question marks for you.

section.title: CLI Command Changes
section.para: A number of commands have been renamed and/or now perform a different function.

section.title: restart
section.para: The restart command now does a true restart and is equivalent to a stop followed by a start.

section.title: load
section.para: The function performed by the Shorewall-4 load command is now performed by the remote_start command.

section.title: reload
section.para: In Shorewall 5, the reload command now performs the same function as the restart command did in Shorewall 4. The action taken by the Shorewall-4 reload command is now performed by the remote_restart command.

For those that can't get used to the idea of using reload in place of restart, a LEGACY_RESTART option has been added to shorewall[6].conf. The option defaults to No but if set to Yes, then the restart command does what it did in earlier releases.

section.title: Upgrading to Shorewall 5
section.para: It is stongly recommended that you first upgrade your installation to a 4.6 release that supports the -A option to the update command; 4.6.13 is preferred.
Once you are on that release, execute the shorewall update -A command (and shorewall6 update -A if you also have Shorewall6).

Finally, add ?FORMAT 2 to each of your macro and action files and be sure that the check command does not produce errors -- if it does, you can shuffle the columns around to make them work on both Shorewall 4 and Shorewall 5.
These steps can also be taken after you upgrade, but your firewall likely won't start or work correctly until you do.
